body: WHILE many movers and shakers have already booked seats on the Concorde, reserved spots in the world's tony restaurants and secured their places on the yachts of their choice for New Year's Eve 1999, many are still in the contemplation stage. Here are what some people say they'd like to do -- or in a few cases what they will be doing -- on the eve
title: The Far-Flung Plans Of Well-Known People

body: While few modern immigrants expect the streets of New York City to be paved with gold, many still find a wide gap between their expectations and reality. For teen-agers, the unfulfilled expectations can be particularly disheartening. ''When I came to America, I came from a country where there was war,'' said 18-year-old Millena Mudryy, who arrived
title: Helping Teen-Age Immigrants Balance Two Worlds

body: Jennifer M. did not drink much in the mornings, maybe a swig of vodka at home or a beer on her way to school, just enough to make a teen-age alcoholic feel that she could face the day. ''I'd wake up in the morning, I'd be depressed,'' said Jennifer, who is 17. ''I couldn't even go to school unless I had a drink.'' She started drinking when she was
title: A Teen-Age Alcoholic Finds Refuge

body: Lou Singer, who guided thousands and thousands of visitors through the other-borough charms of Brooklyn and sang its praises in accents compatible with that environment, died on Tuesday in Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 71 and lived in Brooklyn. The cause was complications after surgery for cancer, his wife, Leona, said. Until his
title: Lou Singer, 71, Guide to the Sights of Brooklyn

body: A Lot of Help From a Friend One definition of a ''cakewalk'' is ''something easy, certain or sure.'' That's not the one that applies to ''Cakewalk,'' Peter Feibleman's play about Lillian Hellman, which opens on Wednesday at the Variety Arts Theater. Instead, try the first definition: ''intricate or eccentric steps.'' In the three years since the
title: On Stage, and Off

body: Assemblyman Jules Polonetsky sees himself as a muckraking politician, the kind of leader who will not let politics get in the way of principles. When he learned that the X-Men, a security firm affiliated with the Nation of Islam, Louis Farrakhan's group, was patrolling a Coney Island housing complex, Mr. Polonetsky made it his mission to oust the
title: X-Men's Foe: Spotlight On a Comer

body: With the first frost of fall comes the instinctive desire for warmth, which requires shelter, food or both. And few people have had as much practice fighting the cold as the Russians. Until recently Russian food has not made its presence felt in New York City. But with the easing of travel restrictions, more Russians are coming to New York.
title: $25 and Under

body: Workers on the front lines of welfare reform, under new orders to deny food stamps to innumerable legal immigrants who had previously qualified for them, are finding that translating Federal law into reality is not coming easily. Field workers are befuddled about what to do when, and some are fighting their torment about the justness of it all.
title: Law Sowing Fear and Confusion at Welfare Offices

body: On the theory that two of anything must be twice as good, the martial arts star Jean-Claude Van Damme has been drawing lately on remembrance of thunks past. This year, in ''Quest,'' he revisited the showy tournament format that provided the narrative spine of his 1987 hit, ''Bloodsport.'' In his new film, ''Maximum Risk,'' which opened yesterday,
title: Double the Fun? Or Just the Bodies?

body: To the Editor: Regrettably, Borough President Howard Golden and Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern have embraced the shortsighted committee of citizens that is opposed to erecting plaques to commemorate Holocaust victims other than Jews (''A Rift Opens Over 'Other Victims' at Holocaust Memorial,'' Aug. 18). It is fitting to honor all Holocaust
title: Separate Plaques Belong In Holocaust Memorial

body: BRIGHTON BEACH is home to roughly 25,000 Russian Jews, many of them elderly, and though the sight of a babushka on the boardwalk is increasingly rare, it's still a place where the knishes are baked, not fried. Next Sunday, a ''noshing tour,'' sponsored by the Brooklyn Center for the Urban Environment, will make its way under the shadow of the D
title: Lessons in Schmoozing and Noshing

body: FYI 2 MAKING IT WORK 3 A New Age preacher with a corporate message gathers a flock in Brooklyn. NEW YORKERS & CO. 4 Why Jerry Nachman, quotemeister and WCBS-TV news director, is heading west again. MOVIE CLOCK 9 What's showing at the local movie houses, today through Thursday. GOOD EATING 10 A tour of the West 40's; Barbetta's regal setting; the
title: ALSO INSIDE

body: In New York City, where more than half the residents are immigrants or the children of immigrants, a sense of panic and confusion has rippled from the shores of Brighton Beach to the streets of Washington Heights as the sweeping Federal welfare bill has become law, affecting millions of people, but perhaps none so immediately as the foreign-born.
title: For New York's Newcomers, Anxiety Over Welfare Law

body: NEW YORK Welfare Bill Sows Anxiety In New York City, where more than half the residents are immigrants or the children of immigrants, a sense of panic and confusion has rippled from the shores of Brighton Beach to the streets of Washington Heights as the far-reaching Federal welfare bill has become law, affecting millions of people, but perhaps
title: METRO DIGEST

body: Futurism of 1939 Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street; (212) 534-1672, ext. 206. ''Drawing the Future: Design Drawings for the 1939 New York World's Fair,'' an exhibition of 40 original illustrations of buildings by architects and designers, starts Wednesday and continues through Jan. 19. Open Wednesday through Saturday, 10
title: Calendar: A Show, Tours And Fairs

body: IT was a pure Marty Markowitz moment. On stage at Wingate Field in East Flatbush last Tuesday, before the Delfonics took to the microphones, Mr. Markowitz stood dressed in a white tuxedo jacket, a crimson scarf poking from the breast pocket and blue jeans, grass-stained at the knees. Microphone in hand, he rattled off the names of the concert's
title: NEW YORKERS & CO.;On Stage With Senator Impresario

body: In a verdict hailed as a major strike against the growing influence of Russian organized crime in the United States, a Federal jury in Brooklyn yesterday convicted a man who the authorities say is the most powerful Russian mobster in the country. After a six-week trial, the jurors took about five hours to convict Vyacheslav Kirillovich Ivankov, 56,
title: Russian Emigre Convicted of Extortion

body: More than 1.6 million people took dips in city pools last year and the city estimates that millions more sprawled out on its beaches. This year promises to be just as busy. The 33 full-sized public pools and 7 public beaches will all be open starting Wednesday through Labor Day. The 33 intermediate and Olympic-size pools listed below admit swimmers
title: Your Tax Dollars at Play: Public Pools and Beaches

body: More than 1.6 million people took dips in city pools last year and the city estimates that millions more sprawled out on its beaches. This year promises to be just as busy. The 33 full-sized public pools and 7 public beaches will all be open starting Wednesday through Labor Day. The 33 intermediate and Olympic-size pools listed below admit swimmers
title: PUBLIC INTEREST;Your Tax Dollars at Play: Public Pools and Beaches

body: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that a proposed deal to lease Coney Island Hospital to a for-profit company includes guarantees that care for the poor would continue at the public hospital at no cost to the city. He called the deal, in which Primary Health Systems, which is based in Delaware, would lease Coney Island Hospital for 49 years,
title: Lease Plan For Hospital Said to Cover Care for Poor

body: Aleksandr Volchkov carries in his wallet a trading card that shows a picture of a hockey player named Aleksandr Volchkov. The man is his father, photographed while playing for the Soviet Union in 1972. It was taken during the Summit Series against Canada, a historic confrontation that widened hockey's horizons. Last season, the younger Volchkov
title: HOCKEY;Russian Brings History and Questions to Draft

body: Leonard Mazin, a New York City high school history teacher, voted against the last teachers contract proposal in December. He had a simple reason: his salary would have been frozen until the fall of 1997. A majority of the city's teachers shared his displeasure, and for the first time in the union's history, rejected a contract. The vote was an
title: Teachers Still See a Pocketful of Reasons to Vote No

body: In chess, in which the arcane, intense battles on the board often pale beside the rivalries away from it, the most controversial figure may not be the 33-year-old world champion, Garry Kasparov, a globe-trotting Muscovite businessman and political commentator whose charismatic, camera-friendly arrogance and hubris are matched only by his
title: Chess in Black and White: 2 Emigres, Father and Son;Pugnacious Manager and Shy, Brilliant Player

body: Two years after defecting with a parcel of underworld secrets, a former Mafia kingpin is expected to surface publicly for the first time today to testify about the mob's alliances with Russian organized crime groups in the New York area. Anthony S. Casso, the former acting boss of the Lucchese crime family in New York City, is scheduled to testify
title: Former Lucchese Crime Boss Is to Testify on Russian Mob

body: Karl Marx has left his mark on the American mall. In the food court at the Shops of Georgetown Mall sits the Taste of Russia, a Russian fast-food booth. Decorated by Russian artists with onion-domed churches in the background, red and green tiles, nesting dolls, a balalaika and a samovar, the Taste of Russia exudes Kremlin kitsch. "No American mall
title: At the Nation's Table: Washington;Kremlin Kitsch At the Mall

body: WE came looking for a better way of life," said Philip Leblang, explaining what brought him and his family to the Amalgamated Warbasse Houses middle-income co-op in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn 32 years ago, when it was newly built. He and his wife, Hilda, are still in the two-bedroom apartment on the third floor that they bought then for
title: PERSPECTIVES;A Big Refinancing at a Middle-Income Co-op

body: The former principal of a Brooklyn elementary school interrupted his week-old trial yesterday to plead guilty to stealing $20,000 from the Board of Education through false work claims and theft of supplies. He also admitted having illegally coerced teachers to participate in political activities at a local club. But in return for these admissions
title: Ex-Principal Pleads Guilty to School Theft

body: Knowing next to no one, Mesut Yaktubay stepped off the plane from Turkey two weeks ago and became an instant regular at Sunny Grocery, a postage-stamp-sized market on an unremarkable corner in Sunnyside, Queens. He does not come for the fava bean paste dip, the fried liver, the shiny pistachio-dappled squares of sobiyet pastry or anything else that
title: In the Queens Mosaic, A Turkish Inlay;Community Takes Root in Sunnyside

body: The job requirements for Poet Laureate of the Borough of Brooklyn are fairly simple: you have to be a published poet recognized by your peers, and you have to have some connection to Kings County. Preferably, you call it home. But the job description of the unpaid three-year appointment depends on whom you ask, even among the literary cadre
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE;What Makes a Borough Bard?

body: With the exception of a patch of struggling grass, little is blossoming at Hunters Point Community Park in Long Island City, Queens. The playground, with its sandbox and one tiny slide, is usually empty; old people seldom sit on the oddly-shaped stainless steel benches. This park, one of the newest in the city, is a virtual wonderland of concrete,
title: Welcome to Donnybrook Park;In Long Island City, a Battle Brews Over a Recreational Space

body: Department of Transportation workers on Colby Court in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, filling in the gaps that had made the streets a slalom course for vehicles during a winter of 21 measurable snowfalls. Articles, page 41. (Edward Keating/The New York Time)
title: Metropolitan Moonscape

body: On a recent misty afternoon, a half-dozen residents of Colby Court -- a small side street in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn -- gathered to watch workers fill in a web of cavernous potholes that had wrenched car wheels out of alignment, forced school-bus drivers to detour, and threatened to devour baby strollers. "It's a long time that this damage has
title: Filling in the Gaps Caused by a Street-Destroying Winter

body: The plague of graffiti, once the international symbol of the subway system's and New York City's financial and spiritual collapse, is beginning to make a comeback on trains and in stations, a decade after a hard-fought campaign virtually eliminated it. To be sure, graffiti has not become the scourge it was more than a decade ago. Subway cars are
title: Subway Graffiti Creeping Back To Haunt Riders;A Threatening Symbol Of the Bad Old Days

body: Vyacheslav Kirillovich Ivankov, a bearded and compactly built man, spends his days in a Brooklyn jail preparing his autobiography -- his version of a supposedly heroic struggle against communist tyranny in the Soviet Union. As Mr. Ivankov labors on his literary efforts, his trial lawyer, Barry I. Slotnick, is preparing a defense that he says will
title: Trial Looms for Man Held as Emigre Godfather

body: Leon M. Goldstein, whose chance to become New York City schools chancellor last fall was derailed by questions over his 24-year tenure as president of Kingsborough Community College, has been cleared of any significant wrongdoing by a City University of New York investigation, officials said yesterday. The investigation by CUNY's office of legal
title: CUNY Investigation Clears Kingsborough College Chief

body: The time passed long ago when the ovens of hulking bread factories like Silvercup and Taystee Bread in Queens filled pockets of the city's landscape with the robust aroma of fresh-baked bread. The Silvercup factory, hard by the East River in Long Island City, is now a television studio. Taystee's huge logo in Flushing beckoned to a web of highways
title: Economic Yeast for a Stale Industry;New York Tries to Stem Loss of City Bakeries

body: A livery-cab driver was found shot to death in the front seat of his car on a Brooklyn street early yesterday, the police said. The police were investigating whether the killing of Mikhail Sharov, 42 -- the fourth of a livery-cab driver in New York this year -- was related to the other three slayings, which ballistics tests showed were committed
title: Another Livery-Cab Driver Is Fatally Shot in Brooklyn

body: IN the city at large, the overheated real estate climate of the 1980's was conjured in a single name: "Donald." But in the corridors and chambers of City Hall where development deals were crafted, another name resonated forcefully: "Sandy." "Sandy" meant Samuel H. Lindenbaum, a seignorial counsel at the firm of Rosenman & Colin and dean of the
title: Lawyers Who Mold The Shape of a City

body: The 1984 movie "This is Spinal Tap," a satirical look at a fictional rock-and-roll band, was called, for lack of a better term, a mockumentary. But what do you call a biographical film about a dead movie star that contains film clips of the star, is narrated by an actor playing her and contains words the star never uttered? Mark Rappaport, who has
title: FILM;Seberg, Through a Cracked Lens

body: Apparently trying to feed a cocaine habit, a lawyer from Staten Island plotted to rob and kill a man in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, but was arrested there yesterday after revealing his plan to a police informer, the police said. The lawyer, 43-year-old Paul Plust, called the informer for help in his plan to rob and kill the man, who has not been
title: S.I. Lawyer Held in Murder Plot

body: Horror and Camp For a penetrating look into the nether regions of home video, many film buffs turn to Videoscope, the magazine published by the Phantom of the Movies, a k a Joe Kane, The Daily News video columnist. Mr. Kane was being half-facetious when he said recently that he watched 10 minutes of 20 films a week. "I have to bail out just for my
title: Home Video

body: Steven Slepack was as bright as anyone who ever came out of Brooklyn, and when he won a full science scholarship to the University of Hawaii he appeared well on his way to a successful career as a marine biologist. But for all his academic promise, Mr. Slepack wasn't cut out for college, or for Hawaii. He took to strumming his banjo on the beach,
title: Steven Slepack, 46, a Street Balloon Virtuoso

body: Fueled by youthful enthusiasm, grand ideals and a distaste for Newt Gingrich, a 30-year-old former assistant district attorney is preparing to take on Representative Jerrold L. Nadler in the Democratic primary on Sept. 10. "I woke up one morning," said the challenger, Brian Steel, "tired of hearing about Newt Gingrich setting the national agenda,
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;A Young Challenger Takes on Nadler -- and in a Way, Gingrich

author: Jennifer Egan is the author of "The InvisibleCircus," a novel, and "Emerald City," a collection of stories just published by Nan A. Talese-Doubleday. This is her first article for the Magazine. Nan Goldin is a New York-based photographer whose last assignment for the Magazine was on gang girls. She is having a retrospective at the Whitney Museum of American Art this fall.
body: AN OCTOBER MORNING IN PARIS. JAMES KING, HER HAIR PULLED back into a ponytail, bounds from an elevator into the lobby of the Hotel de la Tremoille, not far from the Arc de Triomphe, where she has been staying for the past week. "How do I look -- what do you think?" she asks the 20-year-old Julia Samersova, who used to work at Company Management,
title: James is a girl

body: It was a night for the insiders and a night that politicians who normally do not agree on much came together to anoint a candidate. And it was the night after a night on which Democratic loyalists pounded on doors in this sprawling Brooklyn district, lining up proxy votes from those who would be unable to attend the meeting at which Seymour Lachman
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE;Ever the Loyal Democrat, Lachman Reaps His Reward

body: A NARROW side street off the East River where drab, institutional buildings tower over a dusty jumble of cars looked like a suitable enough setting for a Russian lunch. Admit it, the usual impression of Russian food is that besides potatoes and bread, most of it's in short supply. "Hey, hey, hey, that's so wrong!" protested Archduke Dr. Geza von
title: About New York;Imperial Gems, For Viewing And Devouring

body: The New York region rolled up its sleeves yesterday and tackled the gigantic task of coming out from under the Blizzard of '96 as airports and roads reopened, business resumed and people at least tried to return to work. Thousands of commuters jammed suburban buses and train lines, waiting hours to get to work. Bank branches opened, mail was
title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: THE OVERVIEW;Snow-Clogged Region Stirs Back to Life As Novelty Fades and Frustrations Mount

body: CHRIS RAMOS wants his tepee back on Rockaway Parkway. And his sweat lodge, too. So what if the Canarsie man can go to Brighton Beach for a steam bath? He can't learn the ways of the Turtle Clan in Little Odessa. Mr. Ramos is no holdover from Brooklyn's past, when Indian villages dotted its southern reaches. He was taken in by a broad-minded group
title: About New York;A Tepee Comes Down, and Hackles Are Raised

body: E. Jack Beatus, who managed the financial interests of the Tisch family for more than a decade and was a former controller of United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, died on Sunday at Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla, N.Y. He was 58 and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y. The cause was complications after surgery for cancer,
title: E. Jack Beatus, 58, Financial Manager

body: Children were falling asleep atop their parents' luggage carts at La Guardia Airport last night as hundreds of snow-stranded passengers hunkered down for the night in the terminal. Students and teachers in New York City schools knew before they went to bed that they would be staying home today, the first time since 1978 that a snow day had been
title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: THE EFFECTS;Whiteout Forces Shutdown Of Schools, Harbor and U.N.

body: Department of Transportation workers on Colby Court in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, filling in the gaps that had made the streets a slalom course for vehicles during a winter of 21 measurable snowfalls. Articles, page 41. (Edward Keating/The New York Time)
title: Metropolitan Moonscape

body: On a recent misty afternoon, a half-dozen residents of Colby Court -- a small side street in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn -- gathered to watch workers fill in a web of cavernous potholes that had wrenched car wheels out of alignment, forced school-bus drivers to detour, and threatened to devour baby strollers. "It's a long time that this damage has
title: Filling in the Gaps Caused by a Street-Destroying Winter

body: The plague of graffiti, once the international symbol of the subway system's and New York City's financial and spiritual collapse, is beginning to make a comeback on trains and in stations, a decade after a hard-fought campaign virtually eliminated it. To be sure, graffiti has not become the scourge it was more than a decade ago. Subway cars are
title: Subway Graffiti Creeping Back To Haunt Riders;A Threatening Symbol Of the Bad Old Days

body: Vyacheslav Kirillovich Ivankov, a bearded and compactly built man, spends his days in a Brooklyn jail preparing his autobiography -- his version of a supposedly heroic struggle against communist tyranny in the Soviet Union. As Mr. Ivankov labors on his literary efforts, his trial lawyer, Barry I. Slotnick, is preparing a defense that he says will
title: Trial Looms for Man Held as Emigre Godfather

body: Leon M. Goldstein, whose chance to become New York City schools chancellor last fall was derailed by questions over his 24-year tenure as president of Kingsborough Community College, has been cleared of any significant wrongdoing by a City University of New York investigation, officials said yesterday. The investigation by CUNY's office of legal
title: CUNY Investigation Clears Kingsborough College Chief

body: The time passed long ago when the ovens of hulking bread factories like Silvercup and Taystee Bread in Queens filled pockets of the city's landscape with the robust aroma of fresh-baked bread. The Silvercup factory, hard by the East River in Long Island City, is now a television studio. Taystee's huge logo in Flushing beckoned to a web of highways
title: Economic Yeast for a Stale Industry;New York Tries to Stem Loss of City Bakeries

body: A livery-cab driver was found shot to death in the front seat of his car on a Brooklyn street early yesterday, the police said. The police were investigating whether the killing of Mikhail Sharov, 42 -- the fourth of a livery-cab driver in New York this year -- was related to the other three slayings, which ballistics tests showed were committed
title: Another Livery-Cab Driver Is Fatally Shot in Brooklyn

body: IN the city at large, the overheated real estate climate of the 1980's was conjured in a single name: "Donald." But in the corridors and chambers of City Hall where development deals were crafted, another name resonated forcefully: "Sandy." "Sandy" meant Samuel H. Lindenbaum, a seignorial counsel at the firm of Rosenman & Colin and dean of the
title: Lawyers Who Mold The Shape of a City

body: The 1984 movie "This is Spinal Tap," a satirical look at a fictional rock-and-roll band, was called, for lack of a better term, a mockumentary. But what do you call a biographical film about a dead movie star that contains film clips of the star, is narrated by an actor playing her and contains words the star never uttered? Mark Rappaport, who has
title: FILM;Seberg, Through a Cracked Lens

body: Apparently trying to feed a cocaine habit, a lawyer from Staten Island plotted to rob and kill a man in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, but was arrested there yesterday after revealing his plan to a police informer, the police said. The lawyer, 43-year-old Paul Plust, called the informer for help in his plan to rob and kill the man, who has not been
title: S.I. Lawyer Held in Murder Plot

body: Horror and Camp For a penetrating look into the nether regions of home video, many film buffs turn to Videoscope, the magazine published by the Phantom of the Movies, a k a Joe Kane, The Daily News video columnist. Mr. Kane was being half-facetious when he said recently that he watched 10 minutes of 20 films a week. "I have to bail out just for my
title: Home Video

body: Steven Slepack was as bright as anyone who ever came out of Brooklyn, and when he won a full science scholarship to the University of Hawaii he appeared well on his way to a successful career as a marine biologist. But for all his academic promise, Mr. Slepack wasn't cut out for college, or for Hawaii. He took to strumming his banjo on the beach,
title: Steven Slepack, 46, a Street Balloon Virtuoso

body: Fueled by youthful enthusiasm, grand ideals and a distaste for Newt Gingrich, a 30-year-old former assistant district attorney is preparing to take on Representative Jerrold L. Nadler in the Democratic primary on Sept. 10. "I woke up one morning," said the challenger, Brian Steel, "tired of hearing about Newt Gingrich setting the national agenda,
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;A Young Challenger Takes on Nadler -- and in a Way, Gingrich

author: Jennifer Egan is the author of "The InvisibleCircus," a novel, and "Emerald City," a collection of stories just published by Nan A. Talese-Doubleday. This is her first article for the Magazine. Nan Goldin is a New York-based photographer whose last assignment for the Magazine was on gang girls. She is having a retrospective at the Whitney Museum of American Art this fall.
body: AN OCTOBER MORNING IN PARIS. JAMES KING, HER HAIR PULLED back into a ponytail, bounds from an elevator into the lobby of the Hotel de la Tremoille, not far from the Arc de Triomphe, where she has been staying for the past week. "How do I look -- what do you think?" she asks the 20-year-old Julia Samersova, who used to work at Company Management,
title: James is a girl

body: It was a night for the insiders and a night that politicians who normally do not agree on much came together to anoint a candidate. And it was the night after a night on which Democratic loyalists pounded on doors in this sprawling Brooklyn district, lining up proxy votes from those who would be unable to attend the meeting at which Seymour Lachman
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE;Ever the Loyal Democrat, Lachman Reaps His Reward

body: A NARROW side street off the East River where drab, institutional buildings tower over a dusty jumble of cars looked like a suitable enough setting for a Russian lunch. Admit it, the usual impression of Russian food is that besides potatoes and bread, most of it's in short supply. "Hey, hey, hey, that's so wrong!" protested Archduke Dr. Geza von
title: About New York;Imperial Gems, For Viewing And Devouring

body: The New York region rolled up its sleeves yesterday and tackled the gigantic task of coming out from under the Blizzard of '96 as airports and roads reopened, business resumed and people at least tried to return to work. Thousands of commuters jammed suburban buses and train lines, waiting hours to get to work. Bank branches opened, mail was
title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: THE OVERVIEW;Snow-Clogged Region Stirs Back to Life As Novelty Fades and Frustrations Mount

body: CHRIS RAMOS wants his tepee back on Rockaway Parkway. And his sweat lodge, too. So what if the Canarsie man can go to Brighton Beach for a steam bath? He can't learn the ways of the Turtle Clan in Little Odessa. Mr. Ramos is no holdover from Brooklyn's past, when Indian villages dotted its southern reaches. He was taken in by a broad-minded group
title: About New York;A Tepee Comes Down, and Hackles Are Raised

body: E. Jack Beatus, who managed the financial interests of the Tisch family for more than a decade and was a former controller of United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, died on Sunday at Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla, N.Y. He was 58 and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y. The cause was complications after surgery for cancer,
title: E. Jack Beatus, 58, Financial Manager

body: Children were falling asleep atop their parents' luggage carts at La Guardia Airport last night as hundreds of snow-stranded passengers hunkered down for the night in the terminal. Students and teachers in New York City schools knew before they went to bed that they would be staying home today, the first time since 1978 that a snow day had been
title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: THE EFFECTS;Whiteout Forces Shutdown Of Schools, Harbor and U.N.
